newsitem.title: INDIA: Banks', software shares rally on India bourse.
newsitem.headline: Banks', software shares rally on India bourse.

text.p: Blue-chip shares at India's National Stock Exchange (NSE) firmed on Thursday helped by tax breaks and hopes of economic revival, brokers said.
The National Stock Exchange 50-stock index ended 10.30 points, or one percent, higher at a provisional close of 1054.70.
News that Sonia Gandhi has decided to join the Congress party, which came as trading ended for the day, would perk up the market, they said.
"This will give a boost when the markets open tomorrow," Rasesh Maniar, dealer at brokerage Mukesh Babu Securities said.
The Bombay Stock Exchange was closed for a local holiday.
Bank of Baroda rose 7.0 rupees to 84.50, Bank of India 6.7 to 73.50, Federal Bank 6.2 to 95.15 and SBI to 4.55 to 310.
"Financial firms will be the first ones to gain from an economic turnaround," said Ketan Jhaveri, chief dealer at Kotak Securities.
The easier norms brought interest rates down and analysts foresaw better profit margins as the business picks up.
"They are the most representative of the economy," said Ashith Kampani, head of dealing at JM Share & Stock Brokers.
"The focus is clearly shifting to the larger market -- refinery stocks and shares of multinational stocks."
Finance Minister P. Chidambaram on Wednesday proposed to exclude software exports profits from a mininum tax, giving that sector a boost.
NIIT rose 3.95 rupees to 374.25, Infosys 36.6 to 1,463.10, Satyam Computers 3.65 to 74.15 and Tata Unisys 16.05 to 601.05.
Software stocks have been market outperformers in recent months with many brokerage firms giving "buy" recommendations on the companies forecasting strong performance.
Car maker Hindustan Motors said its net profit fell to 393.2 million rupees in the year ended March 31, 1997 from 510.4 million a year ago, due a contract drivers strike which hit production.
Auto components maker Sundram Fasteners said its net profit rose to 320.5 million rupees in the year ended March 31, 1997 from 303.75 million a year earlier.
